meanings.definition: A substance used for whitening walls or other surfaces.
meanings.sent1: The painter applied a fresh coat of whitewash to the fence.
meanings.sent2: The old barn looked bright and clean after a coat of whitewash.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous kids accidentally spilled the whitewash all over themselves.
meanings.sent4: The whitewash on the walls made the room feel airy and spacious.
meanings.sent5: The whitewash gave the garden wall a charming, rustic look.

meanings.definition: To cover up or gloss over faults or wrongdoings.
meanings.sent1: The company tried to whitewash their financial troubles by hiding the losses.
meanings.sent2: He always tries to whitewash his mistakes instead of admitting them.
meanings.sent3: She attempted to whitewash her lateness by blaming traffic.
meanings.sent4: The politician's attempt to whitewash the scandal only made things worse.
meanings.sent5: The student tried to whitewash his plagiarism by claiming it was accidental.

meanings.definition: To make something appear better or more acceptable than it really is.
meanings.sent1: The marketing team tried to whitewash the product's flaws in the advertisement.
meanings.sent2: She always tries to whitewash her failures to save face.
meanings.sent3: His attempt to whitewash his laziness with excuses didn't fool anyone.
meanings.sent4: The fancy packaging was used to whitewash the poor quality of the product.
meanings.sent5: The politician's speech tried to whitewash the harsh reality of the situation.
